title: "Is True Wisdom Built on Paradoxes?"
originalTitle: All Wisdom Is Paradox: A Cross-Cultural Exploration
pullQuotes: “Life can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards.”
“Those who know do not speak. Those who speak do not know.”
“Yet over time the truth of this adage becomes evident: people often grow through adversity, developing resilience and fortitude.”
“A paradox by definition grabs our attention – it makes us stop and think, ‘How can that be true?’”
“a paradox is truth standing on its head to attract attention.”
sceneDescription: In a small lecture hall, a thoughtful philosopher stands in a draped tunic while wearing modern sneakers. A large chalkboard behind him is covered in looping arrows that converge, diverge, then intertwine again in a continuous tangle. A handful of onlookers sit on simple chairs, each with quietly puzzled expressions. The philosopher gazes calmly at the apparent contradictions on the board, suggesting that deeper truths may reside in the very tension between opposing ideas.

Illustration 2 effectively captures the essence of the content by visually representing the complexity and intertwining nature of paradoxes. The philosopher wears modern sneakers with a tunic, highlighting the blend of ancient wisdom with modern thought. The chalkboard's chaotic yet ordered arrows illustrate the concept of paradox well. The style is characteristic of the New Yorker with its subtle humor and clear composition.
